abstractText: The dependence of the actual/e ective ionic concentration on the nominal salt concentration is experimentally investigated for aqueous solutions of NaCl and KCl. The actual ionic bulk density is determined by means of the impedance spectroscopy technique using two approaches for the data analysis: A rst approach scrutinizing the real part's plateau of the cell's electric impedance spectrum versus the bulk density of dopant when the impedance is written in the series representation. A second one via extraction of the ionic density from simultaneously tting of the real and imaginary parts of the impedance spectrum by using the Poisson-Nernst-Planck model. The validity of this procedure reposes on the hypothesis that both the di usion coe cient and the dielectric constant are independent from the salt concentration in the explored range of concentrations. Our experimental results indicate that a rst-order reaction describes well the dissociation phenomenon. The dissociation-association ratio of the reaction has been calculated. Deviations from linearity appear at rather low concentrations of the order of mM.

sections.heading: Abstract
sections.text:
The dependence of the actual/e ective ionic concentration on the nominal salt concentration is
experimentally investigated for aqueous solutions of NaCl and KCl. The actual ionic bulk density
is determined by means of the impedance spectroscopy technique using two approaches for the data
analysis: A rst approach scrutinizing the real part's plateau of the cell's electric impedance spec-
trum versus the bulk density of dopant when the impedance is written in the series representation.
A second one via extraction of the ionic density from simultaneously tting of the real and imaginary
parts of the impedance spectrum by using the Poisson-Nernst-Planck model. The validity of this
procedure reposes on the hypothesis that both the di usion coe cient and the dielectric constant
are independent from the salt concentration in the explored range of concentrations. Our experi-
mental results indicate that a rst-order reaction describes well the dissociation phenomenon. The
dissociation-association ratio of the reaction has been calculated. Deviations from linearity appear
at rather low concentrations of the order of mM.
I. INTRODUCTION
The impedance spectroscopy technique is a powerful method to characterize, from the dielectric point of view, solid and liquid materials, by measuring the electric impedance of a sample versus the frequency of an applied electric signal of small enough amplitude. The theoretical analysis of the response of the sample, in the frequency range where the ions present in the medium contribute to the electric response of the system under consideration, is made by the Poisson-Nernst-Planck (PNP) model [1, 2]. The PNP model is based on the continuity equations for anions and cations and on the equation of Poisson relating the actual potential to the bulk ionic charge density. Several versions of this model have been proposed along the years considering di erent boundary conditions and physical systems [3 9].
The spectra of the impedance's real and imaginary parts in the series representation in the low frequency regime (smaller than one hundred Hz) strongly depend on the physical properties of the electrodes. On contrary, for frequencies larger than approximately one kHz, the electric response of the cell is independent of the electrodes, which can be considered as blocking. In this frequency range, the real part of the impedance presents a large plateau whose amplitude depends only on the di usion coe cient, D, and the bulk density of ions, n, in thermodynamic equilibrium [10]. From the analysis of this part of the spectrum it becomes possible to obtain information about D and n. Taking into account that the di usion coe cient, in the limit of small salt concentrations, is independent of the solute's concentration [11], D can be considered as a known quantity, and n can be derived from this part of the spectrum. Alternatively, D and n can be calculated by tting the real and imaginary parts of the impedance in order to validate the plateau method.
Recently, we have investigated the concentration dependence of the capacitive to inductive transition observed in electrolytic solutions [12], related to the presence of a parasite inductance connected to the connection cables. In that particular case, the parasite inductance was found to be responsible for a cusp in the modulus of reactance, appearing at a well de ned frequency, depending on the salt concentration present in the solution.
Here, we use the same system to investigate the dissociation of NaCl and KCl in water and, in particular, the dependence of the recombination coe cient on the salt concentration. To this end, we calculate the actual/e ective density of ions in the cell and compare it to
the added salt concentration in the water. For the data analysis, we use the plateau method to obtain the actual ion's density. In addition, the e ective ionic concentration is calculated by tting the real and imaginary parts of the impedance.
The remainder of this paper is organized as follows: In Sec. II we outline the PoissonNernst-Planck model used for the analysis of experimental data and provide some useful formulas for deriving the ionic bulk density at the impedance level. In Sec. III we present our experimental results focusing on the dependence of recombination coe cient on salt concentration. This paper ends with summary and conclusions in Sec. IV.

B. Recombination-dissociation phenomenon
In order to derive information on the recombination-dissociation phenomenon, we assume that the decomposition of a salt in water can be described by a chemical reaction whose order depends on the ions generated. In the case where the produced ions have the same valence, the reaction is of rst order, and the neutral molecule A dissociates in two monovalent ions B+ and C−, that is, A = B+ + C−, according to Refs. [12, 14 16]. For an in nite sample (d → ∞) in the absence of any external power supply, the system is at thermodynamic equilibrium, and the bulk density of neutral, positive, and negative species are positionindependent. If we denote by n0, nn, and n the bulk densities of salt molecules that can dissociate, neutral, and charged particles respectively, and by kd and ka the constants of dissociation and recombination, we arrive at
n+ nn = n0, and kd nn = ka n 2. (11)
It follows that the bulk density of ions is given in thermodynamic equilibrium by
n = − kd 2ka + √( kd 2ka )2 + kd ka n0. (12)
The degree of dissociation de ned as ρ = n/n0 follows then as
ρ = −κ 2 + √(κ 2 )2 + κ, (13)
where κ = kd/(kan0). From the measured values of n, and via the nominal concentration n0, it is possible to determine the ratio kd/ka of the reaction.

sections.heading: III. EXPERIMENTAL PART AND ANALYSIS
sections.text:
We measured the impedance spectra of saline solutions composed of (i) potassium cloride (KCl) and (ii) sodium chloride (NaCl), both in Milli-Q water. The concentration of solutions
in NaCl or KCl salt varied from 3 × 1022/m3 up to 1.42 × 1025/m3, see Tab. I. The full description of the saline solution preparation and impedance spectroscopy measurement is given in Ref. [12]. Impedance measurements were performed by applying a harmonic potential of 25 mV in amplitude between the electrodes of the cell containing the electrolyte. Linearity has been tested by varying the amplitude of the applied potential. In what follows we present the impedance spectra of three KCl solutions in order to describe the results and manifest the analysis method. All impedance spectra are given in the Appendix.
Figures 1 3 illustrate the real (R) and imaginary (|X|) parts of the impedance for three typical concentrations of KCl (The spectra for NaCl are similar and are not shown here
for brevity). The appearance of a cusp in the absolute value of the reactance results stems from a parasitic inductance due to the coaxial cables of the experimental set up [12]. This latter inductance was measured equal to L = 2µH [12]. The cusp signals a transition from the capacitive to inductive regime [17]. The dependence of the cusp's frequency position on the ionic concentration reveals the existence of a critical concentration where this frequency shows a jump of approximately two orders of magnitude, i.e., from the MHz regime to a few tens of KHz [12].
In order to obtain the e ective ionic concentration n as function of the nominal one n0 for the various salt solutions and use the obtained results to reckon the dissociation-regeneration coe cient, we follow the protocol of Sec. II. This is based on the experimental value of the resistance at the plateau, Rp. These Rp values are shown in Fig. 4 for both KCl and NaCl. Note the minor di erences in their values which is due to the di erent di usion constants.
For the numerical calculations the di usion coe cient at room temperature of KCl is taken equal to DKCl = 2 × 10−9 m2/s. For NaCl we use DNaCl = 1.6 × 10−9 m2/s respectively [18 20]. Note that in the case of NaCl the di usion coe cient for anions and cations are di erent. Nevertheless, in the plateau range free di usion is important since the ambipolar e ect is crucial only at lower frequencies [21]. The ions are monovalent with q = 1.6 × 10−19 C and the water dielectric constant is taken as ε ∼ 80 × ε0 [11]. The geometrical parameters of the experimental cylindrical cell are: (i) the thickness d = 0.65 × 10−3m, and (ii) the surface area S = π × 10−4m2 of the electrodes. From the expression Rp = kBTd/(2q 2 S D n), and using the experimental values of the plateau resistance, one may calculate the e ective concentration of ions n. In order to test the obtained results, we used them to reproduce the resistance and reactance of the cell for each concentration. This procedure indicates that for low concentrations one can reproduce the experimental spectra fairly well in the regime above the zone where boundary conditions in uence the sample's response. Yet, the method seems to fail above the critical concentration. Therefore, we tried also to t simultaneously R(f) and |X(f)|, as shown in Figs. 5 7. Continuous lines are the result of tting using the PNP model. We t R(f) and |X(f)| only in the frequency range above a few kHz in order to avoid complication due to the electrodes. At low concentrations we nd results compatible to those obtained via the Rp method, while at higher concentrations the obtained results di er by less than ∼ 20%.
Finally Fig. 8 shows the e ective ionic concentration versus the nominal one. Points are
calculated via: (i) the Rp method (blue points for NaCl and green ones for KCl) and (ii)
tting R(f) and |X(f)| (red points for NaCl and gray ones for KCl). Continuous lines show the best ts using Eq. (12). The colors of the continuous line and corresponding points are identical and the dashed line marks complete dissociation. The obtained values for the ratio k = kd/ka are listed here: kNaCl = 2.76 × 1025/m3 and kKCl = 2.54 × 1025/m3 fro the Rp method and kNaCl = 2.21× 1025/m3 and kKCl = 2.04× 1025/m3 from the simultaneous t of R(f) and |X(f)|. Several comments are in the order at this point: (i) Discrepancies among KCl and NaCl e ective concentrations are small and could originate from the approximated di usion constants used in the above analysis. (ii) With increasing concentration of the solution, the association-dissociation e ect has to be taken into account even for concentrations of ∼ 10−3 M. (iii) Other contributions resulting from at distance interactions among ions and among ions and solvent molecules might be important especially at higher concentrations than the ones considered here [22, 23].
Closing, we would like to mention that we have limited our analysis at frequencies above 10 kHz where the in uence of electrodes' properties on the electric response of the cell to the external harmonic excitation is negligible. Moreover, in this frequency regime the ambipolar di usion is not signi cant. Adding a Warburg element in order to take into account the role of electrodes, in series to the impedance evaluated by means of the PNP-model, it is possible to t the experimental data over the entire frequency range. Warburg impedance [24, 25] has the functional form ZW = RWi(ω/ωW ) γ where RW is a real observable having the dimension of a resistance, ωW a typical circular frequency, and γ < 1, are parameters of the model, depending on the state of electrodes and the interface electrode-solution. However, several phenomena contribute to ZW, as the adsorption, ambipolar di usion, roughness of the surface, and others. Considering RW, ωW, and γ as tting parameters it is possible to obtain a good quality t, still without being possible to decipher the physical origin of these parameters. For this reason we limited our analysis at high enough frequencies, as described above.

sections.heading: IV. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text:
To summarize, we have calculated the e ective concentration of ions in NaCl and KCl solutions in water as a function of the nominal salt concentration by the plateau method and by tting the measured impedance using the PNP model. As shown both methods gave compatible results giving credit to our two-fold analysis. Assuming that the salt dissociation is described by a rst-order reaction we calculated the reaction quotient. The analysis has been done in the approximation of constant di usion coe cient and dielectric constant. It would be interesting to compare results of the above described method for evaluation of the e ective ion concentration with measurements on the same samples by other experimental methods, such as conductivity [26] and spectroscopic ones [27 30].
